questions.question_text:
DRAG DROP -
Your company has a Microsoft 365 subscription.
You need to prevent guest users from creating or updating channels.
How should you complete the PowerShell script? To answer, drag the appropriate options to the correct targets. Each option may be used once, more than once, or not at all. You may need to drag the split bar between panes or scroll to view content.
NOTE: Each correct selection is worth one point.
Select and Place:
//IMG//

discussion.content: Yes, this is correct. However, Who Would Do Such Thing Just Like This? It needs to be configure as a policy, not just on already created teams. Whatever Microsoft.

Correct, in exam on 25th of June 2022

The provided answer is correct. Set-AzureADUser and Set-AGGroup do not have any parameters related to Channels or Guest users, leaving the answer to Get-Team and set-Team. Additionally -allowguestCreatedupdatechannels is only available with Set-Team.

I DISAGREE W/THE PROVIDED ANSWER B/C THE Q ASKS FOR USERS, NOT TEAMS OR GPS. The provided links say that the result of Get-Team is a list of TEAMS, not a list of USERS, as the question states. I think it should be Get & Set-AzureADUser.

comments.content: Set-Team (https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/powershell/module/teams/set-team?view=teams-ps) has the correct parameter shown in the questions, e.g. -AllowGuestCreateUpdateChannels, whereas Set-AzureADUser (https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/powershell/module/azuread/set-azureaduser?view=azureadps-2.0) doesn't

questions.question_text:
You manage the Microsoft Teams environment for your company.
Several users report poor call quality.
You need to ensure that a user named Admin5 can review the call quality metrics of all the users at the company. The solution must use the principle of least privilege.
Which role should you assign to Admin5?

comments.content: I agree B. The key here is in the question too. ' Admin5 can review the call quality metrics of ALL the users at the company' as a specialist can only view user information for the specific user being searched for, sure they could it, one by one. But i think the answer they are looking for is B. Teams Communications Support Engineer

Correct is C.

To have access to call quality metrics in Microsoft Teams, the user must have the "Teams Communications Administrator" or "Teams Communications Support Specialist" role. These roles allow the user to view detailed call quality information for all Teams users in the organization. The principle of least privilege should be applied, therefore only users who need this functionality should be assigned to these roles.

yes this is correct 
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/microsoftteams/using-admin-roles#:~:text=There%20are%20four%20Teams%20admin,and%20Teams%20communications%20support%20engineer.

You can review them one by one with specialist.

Remember: principle of least privilege
the key word is "Several users report poor call quality" if it was 1 user then specialist will be ok but B is correct

discussion.content:
Correct answer is B. Key words are "Call Quality Metrics". Specialist can see report about the problem but cannot see the METRICS.
Here are screenshots https://4sysops.com/archives/managing-microsoft-teams-with-role-based-admin-groups/

Using the principle of least privilege the answer should be C I think
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/microsoftteams/using-admin-roles

Selected Answer: B
Specialist can see only one User.

Selected Answer: C
Least Privilege, Specialist is ok but with more minimal features added.

Both can see the report metrics this question appears a lot of time i see.

Selected Answer: C
Reference - https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/microsoftteams/using-admin-roles
Support Specialist can access only if he type the name of the user, I think here is Engineer

Selected Answer: C
Teams Communications Support Engineer: Access, monitor, and troubleshoot tenant's call quality and reliability using data exposed in Call Quality Dashboard (CQD) down to the users who are impacted by poor call quality.
Teams Communications Support Specialist :Access, monitor, and troubleshoot tenant's call quality and reliability using data exposed in Call Quality Dashboard (CQD).

Selected Answer: B
Engineer for All users, whereby C Specialist for specific users

Selected Answer: C
To ensure the principle of least privilege, you should assign the role of "Teams Communications Support Specialist" to Admin5. This role allows Admin5 to review the call quality metrics of all users in the company, while still maintaining a restricted set of permissions. This role strikes a balance between granting the necessary access for troubleshooting and maintaining security by limiting administrative privileges.

To ensure the principle of least privilege, you should assign the role of "Teams Communications Support Specialist" to Admin5. This role allows Admin5 to review the call quality metrics of all users in the company, while still maintaining a restricted set of permissions. This role strikes a balance between granting the necessary access for troubleshooting and maintaining security by limiting administrative privileges.

I think should be B :
Teams Communications Support Engineer:"Access, monitor, and troubleshoot tenant's call quality and reliability using data exposed in Call Quality Dashboard (CQD) down to the users who are impacted by poor call quality."

comments.content: I meant B..

The Teams Communications Support Engineer role provides the necessary permissions for troubleshooting and monitoring call quality metrics in Microsoft Teams. It allows the user to access and review call quality data without granting them excessive administrative control over the Teams environment. The Teams Communications Support Specialist has the permission to watch the call quality but not the call quality metrics. So, the answer is clearly C.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
Although we want least privilege which would be C, The call quality issue is not reported by all so we would need to investigate at a user level. Support Engineer allows for that detail, so I would say B.

Selected Answer: B
B is the correct answer. https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/microsoftteams/using-admin-roles#:~:text=There%20are%20four%20Teams%20admin,and%20Teams%20communications%20support%20engineer.

Keyword is "all users" which cannot be don by "Teams Specialist" since it can only view per user

Tricky question …..
Support engineer >> “ Access, monitor, and troubleshoot tenant's call quality and reliability using data exposed in Call Quality Dashboard (CQD) down to the users who are impacted by poor call quality”
Support Specialist >> “ Access, monitor, and troubleshoot tenant's call quality and reliability using data exposed in Call Quality Dashboard (CQD).”

So when the question says “…can review the CQD of all users at the company” would it be referred to particular users (B - Engineer) or in general (C - Specialist)?
Sorry to answer with a question !!!!

B
Troubleshoot communications issues within Teams by using advanced tools.
Teams Communications Support Engineer

Selected Answer: B
The answer is B.

Specialist can see only one by one users while the Engineer can see all.

But with regards to the least principle. The Teams Communication Support Engineer has least privilege than Teams Administrator. So the answer is B.

Selected Answer: B
Key word "all users", the specialist can not do this.
From the actual MS-700 Learning Collection:
Teams Communications Support Engineer "Access, monitor, and troubleshoot tenant's call quality and reliability using data exposed in Call Quality Dashboard (CQD) down to the users who are impacted by poor call quality."
Teams Communications Support Specialist is missing anything about poor call quality in the same details "Access, monitor, and troubleshoot tenant's call quality and reliability using data exposed in Call Quality Dashboard (CQD)."

comments.content:
I think you are correct (B), Support Specialist doesn't said anything about "down to the users who are impacted by poor call quality" so Support ENGINEER has the least privileges for this task.

- Teams Communications Administrator --> Access, monitor, and troubleshoot tenant's call quality and reliability using data exposed in Call Quality Dashboard (CQD) down to the users who are impacted by poor call quality. Create new call quality reports, update and remove call quality reports as needed. Upload and update CQD building data.

- Teams Communications Support Engineer --> Access, monitor, and troubleshoot tenant's call quality and reliability using data exposed in Call Quality Dashboard (CQD) down to the users who are impacted by poor call quality.

- Teams Communications Support Specialist --> Access, monitor, and troubleshoot tenant's call quality and reliability using data exposed in Call Quality Dashboard (CQD).

On Test 18.01.22
On the test Nov, 12 2021
to be honest I have no idea why MS love making so many roles.. what is the point of specialist role when you have Engineer role?

The question sounds ambiguous.
Given that there are several struggling users, I assume that the admin going to check on each of them separately as overall quality across a big company will say nothing about the particular user. But the only way to filter data by column UPN (username) is to log at least under a Communication Engineer account.
B is correct.

Taking a second look at this, I found further info to support the Communications support Engineer as being the correct answer:

Clues/needs:
1 - there are several users reporting the issue
2 - Need to further/better understand what "call quality metrics" are
3 - principle of least privilege

Call Quality metrics:
Microsoft Teams Metrics – Latency One-Way or Ping In Millisecond and Round-Trip Latency
Jitter (Also Called Packet Inter-Arrival Jitter
Microsoft Teams Metrics – The Network MOS: Network “Mean Opinion Score”

Link to great article on what exactly "call quality metrics" are:
https://martellotech.com/blog/key-metrics-to-assess-ms-teams-user-experience/

With that said, I think we are looking at which role can access EUII data. The Engineer can see EUII data, specialist cannot. 
An engineer is still less than an administrator which maintains the "principle of least privilege"

https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/microsoftteams/cqd-data-and-reports#euii-data

Question states the following:
"Admin5 can review the call quality metrics of all the users at the company"

Support Engineer:
Access, monitor, and troubleshoot tenant's call quality and reliability using data exposed in Call Quality Dashboard (CQD) down to the users who are impacted by poor call quality.

Support Specialist:
Access, monitor, and troubleshoot tenant's call quality and reliability using data exposed in Call Quality Dashboard (CQD).

To me, it appears as though the support specialist can only troubleshoot a more "overall view" of call quality issues for the tenant. 

The Engineer on the other hand, is able to see "down to the users who are impacted by poor call quality." The Engineer has less permissions than the administrator, but more than the Specialist, which would be using the principle of least privilege......

I think this one is correct.

Call quality metrics are simply the quality of the calls, Good/Poor etc. The Specialist role can see all of this information.

This link says as much;
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/microsoftteams/use-call-analytics-to-troubleshoot-poor-call-quality

Also, the question states "The solution must use the principle of least privilege." Engineer is the role a Specialist would escalate cases to for further investigation. 

For me, this should be C.
The Teams communications support engineer (Tier 2 support) sees information in detailed call logs that are hidden from the Teams communications support specialist.

C: Because The Teams communications support specialist (Tier 1 support) handles basic call-quality problems. They don't investigate issues with meetings. Instead, they collect related information and then escalate to a communications support engineer.

From testing in a lab, I can only see a slight difference between Engineer and Specialist, with Engineer having slightly more access. The Engineer role could Export the call quality information, whereas Specialist couldn't. However, they both could view all user call info, so based on least privilege the question asks for "review" and not "export", so I'd say this is C, Specialist role.

comments.content: Changing my mind - Think B is correct! Engineer role covers extra "...down to the users who are impacted by poor call quality." whereas Specialist doesn't.

https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/MicrosoftTeams/use-call-analytics-to-troubleshoot-poor-call-quality#what-does-each-teams-support-role-do

Differences here are that only the Engineer is able to view the Advanced area which contains device name, IP addresses, SSID, etc. This isn't an area for "call quality metrics".

However, in the description of the role it states:
"Description:Users in this role can troubleshoot communication issues within Microsoft Teams & Skype for Business using the user call troubleshooting tools in the Microsoft Teams & Skype for Business admin center. Users in this role can only view user details in the call for the specific user they have looked up."

Do have have to specifically lookup for all users at once, or just be able to view all users whether its one by one?!? Microsoft man...

forget it, Specialist < Engineer

Access user profile page for troubleshooting calls in Call Analytics. Can only view user information for the SPECIFIC USER being searched for.

questions.question_text:
Your company has a Microsoft 365 subscription that contains a team named Sales.
You need to recommend a solution to ensure that all guest users who are members of Sales receive an email message each year to verify that they want to remain in the team.
What should you include in the recommendation?

discussion.content: A and D. Use GPO for Windows 10 machines and Configure Q0s in Meeting settings in teams Admin portal
On exam 04-Mar-2022
Was on test on 22.08.2022

Selected Answer: AD
correct answer is AD
On Test 18.01.22
On the test Nov, 12 2021
yes, that's right. You have to turn on QoS in Teams admin center and apply Port Based Access Control list to identify and mark all packets.

Correct. 
Meeting settings - Network - Insert Quality of Service (QoS) markers for real-time media traffic. And use GPO.

questions.question_text:
Your company deploys a Quality of Service (QoS) solution to its network.
You recently deployed Microsoft Teams for all users. Each user uses a domain-joined computer that runs Windows 10.
The users report poor audio quality when they use Microsoft Teams from the network.
You discover that the media traffic from Microsoft Teams is NOT processed by the QoS solution.
You need to ensure that all the media traffic is processed by the QoS solution.
Which two actions should you perform? Each correct answer presents part of the solution.
NOTE: Each correct selection is worth one point.

choices.E: From the Microsoft Teams admin center, turn on logging for the device configuration profile.
choices.A: From the Microsoft Teams admin center, set Insert Quality of Service (QoS) markers for real-time media traffic to On.
choices.C: From PowerShell, run the Set-CsQoEConfiguration cmdlet.
choices.D: From Group Policy Management, create a Group Policy Object (GPO) that contains the Policy-based QoS settings, and then link the GPO to the domain.
choices.B: From the Microsoft Teams client, select a certified Microsoft Teams audio device.
